Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the baseline MQ-4C Triton Unmanned Air System (UAS) to deliver the Multi-Intelligence (Multi-INT) configuration. MQ-4C Triton aircraft and ground stations in the Multi-INT configuration are integral to the Navy's Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) transition plan. Modifications will include sensor, electronics and communication subsystems that provide Triton's Integrated Functional Capability 4 (IFC 4), Multi-Intelligence configuration. 

The MQ-4C Triton Unmanned Air System (UAS) is integral to recapitalizing the Navy's Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Force. The MQ-4C Triton UAS provides a persistent maritime and littoral ISR data collection and dissemination capability to the fleet, serving as a force multiplier for the Joint Force and Fleet Commander, enhancing situational awareness of the battle space and shortening the sensor-to-shooter kill chain. Teamed with its manned-capability counterpart, the P-8A, Triton will be a key component of the Navy's family of systems to achieve maritime domain awareness. The MQ-4C air vehicle, mission control system, specialized sensors, and communications suite will play a significant role in achieving the Navy's strategic vision for the 21st century. The Triton system as a persistence ISR enabler provides the supported combatant commander and fleet commander with unparalleled situational awareness of the maritime battle space to develop and sustain the Common Operational Tactical Picture (COTP). The system will also serve as a Fleet response plan enabler with a persistent, global force offering to provide critical trip wire information for intelligence preparation of the environment. Triton will connect to both the Global Information Grid and the Distributed Common Ground System-Navy information backbone to provide the Warfighter with unprecedented levels of battlespace awareness to synchronize actions necessary to maintain maritime Full Spectrum Superiority. Triton's on-station time and range enables unmatched awareness of the maritime battlespace by sustaining the COTP for Surface Warfare and the Overseas Contingency Operation.

MQ-4C Triton includes an endurance-class UAS that will operate from land-based sites around the world. Unmanned aircraft at each operating location will provide persistent maritime ISR by being airborne 24 hours a day, 7 days a week out to ranges of 2,000 nautical miles. Worldwide access will be achieved by providing coverage to nearly all the world's high-density sea-lanes, littorals and areas of national interest from its operating locations. Triton will leverage the Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Forces community to enhance manpower, training and maintenance efficiencies. 

MQ-4C Triton UAS sensors will provide detection, classification, tracking and identification of maritime targets. Sensors to fulfill mission requirements include maritime radar, electro-optical/infrared and Electronic Support Measures systems. Additionally, Triton will have a communications relay capability linking dispersed forces in the theater of operation and serving as a node in the Navy's networked strategy. The MQ-4C Triton UAS will support the Fleet Commander's common operational tactical picture COTP of the battlespace, day and night. The UAS will cue other Navy assets for further situational investigation and/or attack, and will also provide battle damage assessment of the area of interest. Tactical-level data analysis will occur in real-time at shore-based Mission Control Systems via satellite communications. Further intelligence exploitation can be conducted at shore-based sites or aboard Carrier Vessel Nuclear/Landing Helicopter Dock ships.

The aircraft inventory objective for the MQ-4C Triton in FY 2020 is projected to be 2 System Development and Demonstration, 1 System Demonstration Test Article, and 6 LRIP aircraft.


DT&E:  4Q FY12 - 4Q FY20
OT&E:  1Q FY21 - 3Q FY21
FRP:   4Q FY21

Justification.val: FY 2020 request resources hardware and installation costs to upgrade aircraft (qty 1) and ground stations (qty 1) to the Integrated Functional Capability 4.0 (IFC 4.0) configuration.  The FY 2020 request reflects completion of IFC 4.0 aircraft and Main and Forward Operating Base upgrades that were originally planned in prior years.

Name.@footnote: Training equipment upgrade aligns with IFC 4.0 MOB/FOB upgrade.
Other Support funds government support for aircraft modification, installation, calibration and testing required for acceptance.

2.1.1) IFC 4.0 Aircraft Upgrade B kit - Organic

Name.@footnote: IFC 4.0 Main and Forward Operating Base installation upgrade can be completed in parallel with IFC 4.0 aircraft installation upgrade.
Name.val: 2.1.2) IFC 4.0 Main and Forward Operating Base upgrade - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: FY 2019 nonrecurring required to execute IFC 4.0 upgrade.
MOB/FOB quantity of 4 represents 2 MOBs and 2 FOBs.  Unit costs will vary because the MOB contains additional mission systems and operator workstations over the FOB.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor:: Installation Name: IFC 4.0 Aircraft Upgrade A Kit
Contractor:: Installation Name: IFC 4.0 Main and Forward Operating Base upgrade

Description.val:
The purpose of this OSIP is to upgrade baseline aircraft and ground stations (Main Operating Base (MOB) and Forward Operating Base (FOB)) to IFC 4 and future configurations. The ground stations also include the stand-alone MOB used for training. The technical components of the IFC 4 retrofits for the unmanned aircraft include, but are not limited to: addition of Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) antennas and systems, new High Gain Common Data Link (CDL) antenna and associated avionics, addition of a Keyed Broad Area Maritime Surveillance Airborne Recorder (K-BAR), new Airborne Mission Processor, new airborne network hardware, addition of high assurance internet protocol encryptors (HAIPE), new Voice Communications, and new Cross Domain Solution (CDS), and air vehicle aircraft modifications to mitigate Electromagnetic Interference (EMI).

The technical components of the IFC 4 retrofits for the MOB/FOB include, but are not limited to: addition of a K-BAR docking station, addition of Mission Execution equipment (replaces existing payload hardware), new communication and network equipment, addition of CDS, and addition of a Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF) Data Facility.

Development Status/Major Development Milestones: Multi-INT Early Operational Capability FY 2021 and Triton Initial Operational Capability FY 2021.
